sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; enables you to convert the name of a file, or the contents of a plain-text file, from a legacy character encoding to UTF-8 encoding.

When converting file name, &app; processes regular file, folder file and symbolic link. When converting file content, it handles regular plain text file only. &app; support special file type also, curently &app; only support .tar, .tar.gz, .tar.bz2, .zip and .tar.Z compress or archive format.

&app; will ignore most of non-plain text file such as binary file, office document and image file. It might produce unexpected result if convert these type of files forcibly. Internally &app; uses file(1) utility to determine whether one file is plain text file or not.

note.para: The default internal character encoding in the Sun Java Desktop System is UTF-8 encoding, and the default locale is the UTF-8 locale. If not converted, files with legacy character encoding are displayed as meaningless text. For more information about UTF-8, please visit http://www.unicode.org.

sect2.title: To Start &appname;
sect2.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para: Click Launch, then choose ApplicationsUtilitiesFile Encoding Examiner.
Execute the following command: fsexam

sect2.title: When You Start &appname;
sect2.para: When you start &app;, the following window is displayed:
The &app; window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: The menus on the menubar contain all of the commands that you need to work with files in &app;.
The toolbar buttons on the toolbar contain commands that you frequently use to work with files in &app;.
The files tree display the contents of the current directory.
The report area displays the conversion result or dry run result.
The statusbar displays information about current &app; activity.

sect2.para: When you right-click in the &app; window, the application displays a popup menu. The popup menu contains the most common commands.
This manual documents functionality from the menubar.

sect2.title: To Select a File or Directory
sect2.para: Choose FileOpen..., then select the file or directory whose character encoding you want to change.
If you select a directory, all of the files and subdirectories in that directory are displayed in the file tree.

sect2.title: To Search Files
sect2.para: Choose FileSearch for files..., then input the search criterias to search according to them. To stop searching, choose FileStop Searching.
Internally &app; use find(1) utility to search files.

sect2.title: To Convert the Name or Content of Files
sect2.para: Perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select the file or directory as described in , or search files as described in .
Choose EditConvert.

If the current conversion mode is name conversion, the &appname; name conversion dialog is displayed. If the current conversion mode is content conversion mode, the &appname; content conversion dialog is displayed. For information on how to display or hide the File Encoding Examiner name conversion or File Encoding Examiner content conversion dialog, see .
The &appname; name conversion dialog or &appname; content conversion dialog displays a list of character encodings that &app; can use to convert the file name or content.
Select an encoding, then click OK.

sect2.para: After &app; finish conversion, the report pane displays conversion information or any other error information, the statusbar displays display one summary report.
sect2.note: Please make sure the files' name are UTF-8 already before converting file content. If not, use name conversion mode to convert file name first.

sect2.title: To Forcibly Convert
sect2.para: Perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select the file or directory as described in , or search files as described in .
Choose EditForcibly Convert.

sect2.para: &app; convert selected files without detecting whether the file is UTF-8 already or not.

sect2.title: To Dry Run
sect2.para: Perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select the file or directory as described in , or search files as described in .
Choose EditDry Run.

sect2.para: &app; dry run convert selected files and don't modify any file name or content on the disk. The dry run result displays in Dryrun Result tab. Later you can perform scenario based conversion based on the dry run result. For more information about scenario based conversion, refer to .

sect2.title: To Scenario Based Conversion
sect2.para: Perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Perform dry run conversion as described in .
Choose EditScenario.

sect2.para: Scenario based conversion use the first candidate in dry run result to convert file. If the first candidate is not what you want, you can delete the it and make the right candidate appear firstly. The dry run result is format sensitive, for more information about dry run format, please refer fsexam(4) man page.

sect2.title: To Undo the Last Action
sect2.para: Choose EditUndo.

sect2.title: To Restore the Original File name or content
sect2.para: Perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select the file or directory as described in , or search files as described in .
Choose EditRestore.

sect2.para: &app; restores the original file name in name conversion mode and restores file content in content conversion mode.

note.para: If you convert file content first, then convert file name, you may can't restore file content before you restore file name, as the name of file is changed.

sect2.title: To Clear Search Result
sect2.para: Perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose EditClear Search Result.

sect2.title: To Change Conversion Mode
sect2.para: Perform the following steps:

listitem.para: To change the current conversion mode to name conversion, choose EditName Conversion Mode.
To change the current conversion mode to content conversion, choose EditContent Conversion Mode.

sect2.title: To Display the Report Pane
sect2.para: Choose ViewReport Pane.
The report pane displays the directory name, and a list of converted files with corresponding conversion information.

sect2.title: To Display the Dry Run Result
sect2.para: Choose ViewDry Run Result Pane.

sect2.title: To Display the Search Result
sect2.para: Choose ViewSearch Result.

sect2.title: To Preview the Contents of a File
sect2.para: Perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select one single file, as described in .
Choose ViewPreview Content.

sect2.para: If &app; successfully previews the file contents, a popup window displays the first part of the file. Click on the popup window to close the window.
If the preview fails, the statusbar displays an error message.

sect1.title: Preferences
sect1.para: To configure &app;, choose EditPreferences. The following &appname; Preferences dialog is displayed.
The &app; preference dialog contains the following elements:

listitem.para: Auto Detection: Select this option to enable encoding automatic detection. &app; appends automatic detected encoding into the encoding list. Its priority is lower than the encodings in encoding list.

note.para: Sometime &app; may produce wrong encoding, please use it with caution when the Auto Conversion is checked also.

listitem.para: Auto Conversion: Select this option to specify that &app; uses the first suitable legacy character encoding in the Encoding list to convert the name or content of files and subdirectories to UTF-8 encoding. If you do not select this option, &app; displays the File System Examiner name conversion dialog or &appname; content conversion dialog, as described in .
Recursive Mode: Select this option to convert the name or content of all files and subdirectories in the selected directory.
Handle Hidden Files: Select this option to handle hidden files.
Handle Remote Files: Select this option to handle non-local files, such as NFS files.

Follow Symbolic link: Select this option to follow symbolic link. If the target of symbolic link is directory and Recursive Mode is selected, files and subdirectories under this directory will be converted also.

Don't Check Symlink Content: By default, &app; re-create symbolic link after the target file name of the symbolic link is converted. Use this option if you know there is no symbolic link in the files which you want to convert.
Special File Handling: Select this option to enable special file type support. Currently &app; support compress or archive file only.
Archive or Compress files: Select this option to files in the archive or compress file. Currently &app; support .tar, .tar.gz, .tar.bz2, .tar.Z and .zip file.
listitem.note: As shown in the NOTES section of the tar(1) man page, if an archive is created that contains files whose names were created by processes running in multiple or different locales, a locale that uses a full 8-bit coding space, i.e., 0x0 to 0xff, such as en_US.ISO8859-1 should be used both to create the archive and to extract files from the archive. Due to that, when you specify COMPRESS module with -E option, fsexam(1) tries to use en_US.ISO8859-1, fr_FR.ISO8859-1, de_DE.ISO8859-1, es_ES.ISO8859-1,it_IT.ISO8859-1, or sv_SE.ISO8859-1 locales. If there is no such locale in the current system, use of this option is ignored and a warning message is issued.

listitem.para: Use Log File: Select this option to specify &app; to write log information to specified log file. By default, &app; don't use log file, as it will display these information in Report Pane. Refer to to display the report pane.
Log File Name: Specify the name of log file.
History Length: Specify the length of history file. The minimal length is 30.

note.para: Batch convert multiple files count as one in the history file.

listitem.para: Displays a list of legacy character encodings available for the current language. When installing &appname;, one predefined encoding list for each language which contains the most popular encodings used for this language will be installed also.

Click Up to move an encoding up the list. Click Down to move an encoding down the list. Click Delete to delete an encoding from the list. Click Add to add encoding into the list. Click Save to save the current encoding list permanently. By default the changes in encoding list influence the current session only. &app; will restore to the last state after rerun it.
